(Ibn-'Abbád, K.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He made to tarry; to tarry and wait,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">expect;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to be patient, and tarry, and wait,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">expect.</hi> (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) <pb n="48"/>

                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">آرض</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">آرض</orth>
                  </form>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِيْرَاضٌ</foreign>: see 5.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">مَا آرَضُ هذَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">المَكَانَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">How abundant is the herbage</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">عُشْب</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">of this place!</hi> or, as some say, <foreign lang="ar">مَا آرَضَ هذِهِ الأَرْضَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">How level,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">soft, and productive, and good, is this land!</hi> (Lh, AHn.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">آرَضَهُ</foreign>, (S, K, [in the CK, incorrectly, <foreign lang="ar">اَرَضَهُ</foreign>,]) inf. n. as above, (S,) <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (God) <hi rend="ital">caused him to be affected with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">زُكَام</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">rheum</hi>]. (S, K.)    </entryFree>29:T2ffe,<entryFree id="n579" key="الأَرْضُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">الأَرْضُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">The earth;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">that whereon are mankind:</hi> (TA:) [and <hi rend="ital">earth, as opposed to heaven:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the ground,</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">the surface of the earth, on which we tread and sit and lie;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the floor:</hi> without <foreign lang="ar">ال</foreign> signifying <hi rend="ital">a land,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">country:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a piece of land</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ground:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">land,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">soil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ground, considered in relation to its quality:</hi>] it is fem.: (S, A, Msb, K:) and is a coll. gen. n.; (S, A, K;) of which the n. un. should be <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَةٌ</foreign>, but this they did not say: (S:) or a pl. having no sing.; (A, K;) for <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَةٌ</foreign> has not been heard: (K:) its pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضَاتٌ</foreign>, (S, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَاتٌ</foreign>, (TA,) for they sometimes form the pl. of a word which has not the fem. <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign> with <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign>, as in the instance of <foreign lang="ar">عُرُسَاتٌ</foreign>; (S;) and <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضُونَ</foreign>, [which is more common,] (AZ, AHn, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with fet-h to the <foreign lang="ar">ر</foreign>, (AZ, AHn, Mgh, Msb,) and with <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign>, though a fem. has not its pl. formed [regularly] with <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign> unless it is of the defective kind, like <foreign lang="ar">ثُبَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ظُبَةٌ</foreign>, but they have made the <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign> [in this instance] a substitute for the <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ت</foreign> which they have elided [from <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضَاتٌ</foreign>], and have left the fet-hah of the <foreign lang="ar">ر</foreign> as it was; (S;) but they also said <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضُونَ</foreign>, (AZ, AHn, S,) sometimes, making the <foreign lang="ar">ر</foreign> quiescent; (S;) and <foreign lang="ar">أُرُوضٌ</foreign> (AZ, AHn, Msb, K) is sometimes used as a pl., as in the saying <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَكْثَرَ أُرُوضَ بَنِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">How many are the lands of the sons of such a one!</hi>]; (TA;) and another [and very common] pl. is [<foreign lang="ar">أَرَاضٍ</foreign>, with the article written] <foreign lang="ar">الأَرَاضِى</foreign>, contr. to rule, (S, Msb, K,) as though they had formed a pl. from <foreign lang="ar">آرُضٌ</foreign>; (S;) thus written in all the copies of the S; [accord. to SM; but in one copy of the S, I find <foreign lang="ar">كَأَنَّهُمْ جَمَعُوا ااراضًا</foreign>; and in another, <foreign lang="ar">ارضًا</foreign>;] and in one copy [is added], “ thus it is found in his [J's] handwriting; ” but IB says that correctly he should have said <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَى</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">أَرْطَى</foreign>; for as to <foreign lang="ar">آرُضٌ</foreign>, its regular pl. would be <foreign lang="ar">أَوَارِضُ</foreign>; and [SM says] I have found it observed in a marginal note to the S that the pl. of <foreign lang="ar">آرُضٌ</foreign> would be <foreign lang="ar">أَآرِضُ</foreign>, like as <foreign lang="ar">أَكَالِبُ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَكْلُبٌ</foreign>; and wherefore did he not say that <foreign lang="ar">الاراضى</foreign> is a pl. of an unused sing., like <foreign lang="ar">لَيَالٍ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَهَالٍ</foreign>, so that it is as though it were pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَاةٌ</foreign>, like as <foreign lang="ar">لَيَالٍ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">لَيْلَاةٌ</foreign>? yet if any one should propose the plea that it may be formed by transposition from <foreign lang="ar">أَآرِضُ</foreign>, he would not say what is improbable; its measure being in this case <foreign lang="ar">أَعَالِفُ</foreign>; the word being <foreign lang="ar">أَرَاضِئُ</foreign>, and the <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> being changed into <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-Khattáb, (S,) <foreign lang="ar">آرَاضٌ</foreign> is also a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign>, (S, K,) like as <foreign lang="ar">آهَالٌ</foreign> is a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَهْلٌ</foreign>; (S;) but IB says that, in the opinion of the critics, the truth with respect to what is related on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb is, that from <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَهْلٌ</foreign> are formed <foreign lang="ar">أَرَاضٍ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَهَالٍ</foreign>, as though they were pls. of <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضَاةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَهْلَاةٌ</foreign>; like as they said <foreign lang="ar">لَيْلَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">لَيَال</foreign>, as though this were pl. of <foreign lang="ar">لَيْلَاةٌ</foreign>. (TA.) It is said in proverbs, <foreign lang="ar">أَجْمَعُ مِنَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الأَرْضِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">More comprehensive than the earth</hi>]: (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">آمَنُ مِنَ الأَرْضِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">More trustworthy than the earth,</hi> in which treasures are securely buried]: and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَدُّ مِنَ الأَرْضِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Harder than the earth,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ground</hi>]: (A, TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">أَذَلُّ مِنَ الأَرْضِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">More vile,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">more submissive, than the earth,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ground</hi>]. (TA.) And you say, <foreign lang="ar">مَنْ أَطَاعَنِى كُنْتُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لَهُ أَرْضَا</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Whoso obeyeth me, I will be to him</hi> as <hi rend="ital">ground</hi> whereon one treads]; denoting submissiveness. (A, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ إِنٌ ضُرِبَ فَأَرْضٌ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Such one, if he be beaten, is</hi> like <hi rend="ital">ground</hi>]; i. e. he cares not for beating. (A, TA.) One says also, <foreign lang="ar">لَا أَرْضَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لَكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Mayest thou have no land,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">country!</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thou hast no land,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">country</hi>]; like as one says, <foreign lang="ar">لَا أُمَّ لَكَ</foreign>. (S, K,)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [And hence,] <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ ابْنُ أَرْضٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He is a stranger,</hi> (A, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">of whom neither father nor mother is known.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">اِبْنُ الأَرْضِ</foreign> [with the art. <foreign lang="ar">ال</foreign> prefixed to the latter word] is <hi rend="ital">A certain plant,</hi> (AHn, K,) <hi rend="ital">which comes forth upon the summits of the</hi> [<hi rend="ital">hills called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">آكَام</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">having a stem</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">أَصْل</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">but not growing tall,</hi> (AHn,) <hi rend="ital">which resembles hair, and is eaten,</hi> (AHn, K,) <hi rend="ital">and quickly dries up;</hi> (AHn;) <hi rend="ital">a species of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَقْل</foreign>, as also <foreign lang="ar">بِنْتُ الأَرْضِ</foreign>: (S in art. <foreign lang="ar">بنى</foreign>:) and <foreign lang="ar">بَنَاتُ الأَرْضِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">plants:</hi> (M in art. <foreign lang="ar">بسر</foreign>:) and <hi rend="ital">the places which are concealed from the pastor.</hi> (S in that art.) Also <hi rend="ital">The pool that is left by a torrent:</hi> (T in art. <foreign lang="ar">بنى</foreign>:) and <foreign lang="ar">بَنَاتُ الأَرْضِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">pools in which are remains of water:</hi> (IAar in TA art. <foreign lang="ar">بسر</foreign>:) and <hi rend="ital">rivulets.</hi> (T in art. <foreign lang="ar">بنى</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign> is also used to signify <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">A carpet;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">anything that is spread:</hi> and in this sense, in poetry, it is sometimes made masc. (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  And <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Anything that is low.</hi> (S, K.) And <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  The <hi rend="ital">lower,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lowest, part of the legs</hi> of a horse or the like: (S, K:) or the <hi rend="ital">legs</hi> of a camel or of a horse or the like: and the <hi rend="ital">part that is next to the ground thereof.</hi> (TA.) You say <foreign lang="ar">بَعِيرٌ شَدِيدُ الأَرْضِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A camel strong in the legs.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">فَرَسٌ بَعِيدٌ مَا بَيْمَ أَرْضِهِ وَسَمَائِهِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A horse that is large and tall.</hi> (A, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  Also, of a man, <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  The <hi rend="ital">knees and what is beneath,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">below,</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">after,</hi>) <hi rend="ital">them.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And of a sandal, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [The <hi rend="ital">lower surface of the sole;</hi>] the <hi rend="ital">part that touches the ground.</hi> (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A febrile shivering; a tremor:</hi> (S, K:) or <hi rend="ital">vertigo:</hi> or it signifies also <hi rend="ital">vertigo arising from a relaxed state, and occasioning a defluxion from the nose and eyes.</hi> (TA.) I'Ab is related to have said, on the occasion of an earthquake, <foreign lang="ar">أَزُلْزِلَتِ الأَرْضُ أَمْ بِى أَرْضٌ</foreign>, (S,) i. e. [<hi rend="ital">Hath the earth been made to quake, or is there in me</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a tremor?</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a vertigo?</hi> (TA.) [<foreign lang="ar">أَهْلُ الأَرْضِ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">A certain class of the jinn,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">genii;</hi> by whom human beings are believed to be possessed, and affected by an involuntary tremor; whence it seems that this appellation may perhaps be from <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ</foreign> as signifying “ a tremor. ” See <foreign lang="ar">مَأْرُوضٌ</foreign>: and see <foreign lang="ar">خَبَلٌ</foreign>, as explained in the S.]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Rheum;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">زُكَامٌ</foreign>: (S, K:) in this sense masc.; or, accord. to Kr, fem., on the authority of Ibn-Ahmar.                   <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَرَضَةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [The <hi rend="ital">wood-fretter;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a certain insect that eats wood,</hi> (S A, Msb, K,) <hi rend="ital">well known;</hi> (A, K;) it is <hi rend="ital">a white worm, resembling the ant, appearing in the days of the</hi> [<hi rend="ital">season called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">رَبِيع</foreign>: (TA:) there are two kinds: <hi rend="ital">one kind is small, like the large of the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ذَرّ</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">grubs of ants</hi>]; <hi rend="ital">and this is the bane of wood in particular:</hi> (AHn, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">this kind is the bane of wood and of other things, and is a white worm with a black head, not having wings, and it penetrates into the earth, and builds for itself a habitation of clay,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">soil; and this is said to be that which ate the staff of Solomon</hi> [as is related in the Kur xxxiv. 13, where it is called <foreign lang="ar">دَابَّةُ الأَرْضِ</foreign>, as is said in the A]: (TA:) the other kind [<hi rend="ital">is the termite,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">white ant; termes</hi> 
                  <hi rend="ital">fatale</hi> of Linn.; called by Forskål (in his Descr. Animalium &amp;c., p. 96,) <hi rend="ital">termes arda, destructor; and this</hi>] <hi rend="ital">is like a large common ant, having wings; it is the bane of everything that is of wood, and of plants; except that it does not attack what is moist, or succulent; and it has legs:</hi> (AHn, TA:) <pb n="49"/> the pl. is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n583-1" target="أَرَضٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n580"/></foreign> (AHn, Msb, TA) and <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضَاتٌ</foreign>; (Msb;) or, as some [more properly] say, <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضٌ</foreign> is a quasi-pl. [or coll. gen.] n. (AHn, TA.) It is said in a prov., <foreign lang="ar">آكَلُ مِنَ الأَرَضَةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">More consuming than the wood-fretter,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the termite</hi>]. (TA.) And in another, <foreign lang="ar">أَفْسَدُ مِنَ الأَرَضَةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">More marring,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">injuring,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">destructive, than the wood-fretter,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the termite.</hi>] (A, TA.)    </entryFree>2c:Tc39,<entryFree id="n587" key="أَرِيضٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَرِيضٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> part. n. of <foreign lang="ar">أَرُضَ</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  You say <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ أَرِيضَةٌ</foreign> (S, A, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n587-1" target="أَرِضَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n584"/></foreign> (TA) <hi rend="ital">Land that is thriving,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">productive;</hi> (S, A, K;) <hi rend="ital">pleasing to the eye;</hi> (AA, S, A, K;) <hi rend="ital">and disposed by nature to yield good produce:</hi> (A, K, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">fruitful; increasing in plants</hi> or <hi rend="ital">herbage:</hi> (IAar:) or <hi rend="ital">level,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">soft:</hi> (ISh:) or <hi rend="ital">that collects moisture, and becomes luxuriant with herbage; that is soft to tread upon, pleasant to sit upon, productive, and good in its herbage</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vegetation:</hi> (AHn:) it also signifies <hi rend="ital">a wide land;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">عَرِيضَةٌ</foreign>: (TA:) and <foreign lang="ar">إِرَاضٌٍ</foreign> [as pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَرِيضٌ</foreign>] is syn. with <foreign lang="ar">عِرَاضٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">وِسَاع</foreign>; (AA, K, TA;) as though the <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> were a substitute for the <foreign lang="ar">ع</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَرِيضٌ</foreign> is also an imitative sequent to <foreign lang="ar">عَرِيضٌ</foreign>; (S, K;) as in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">أَرِيضٌ شَىْءٌ عَرِيضٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A very wide thing</hi>]: (S:) or it signifies <hi rend="ital">fat,</hi> as an epithet: (K:) some use it in this sense without <foreign lang="ar">عرِيض</foreign>, applied to a kid. (S.) And you say, <foreign lang="ar">اِمْرَأَةٌ عَرِيضَةٌ أَرِيضَةٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A very wide,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wide and fat, woman;</hi> or, as seems to be indicated in the TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">عرَض</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">prolific and perfect</hi>]; and in like manner,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n587-2" target="مُؤْرِضَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n589"/></foreign>. (TA.) You say also <foreign lang="ar">رَجُلٌ أَرِيضٌ</foreign>, (S,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n587-3" target="أَرُوضٌ" n="3" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n586"/>لِلْخَيْرِ</foreign>, (A,) <hi rend="ital">A man lowly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">submissive;</hi> (S;) <hi rend="ital">naturally disposed to good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to do good.</hi> (S, A.) And <foreign lang="ar">نَفْسٌ وَاسِعٌ أَرِيضٌ</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">رَابِطٌ</foreign>.    </entryFree>2d:T655,<entryFree id="n590" key="مَأْرُوضٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مَأْرُوضٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> Wood <hi rend="ital">eaten by the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَرَضَة</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">woodfretter,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">termite,</hi> but generally meaning the former]; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n590-1" target="أَرْضٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n573"/></foreign>. (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  A person <hi rend="ital">affected with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">خَبَل</foreign> [q. v.] <hi rend="ital">from the jinn,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">genii, and</hi> [<hi rend="ital">what are called</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">أَهْلُ الأَرْضِ</foreign>, (S, K,) i. e. (so accord. to the S and TA, but in the K “ and ”) <hi rend="ital">he who moves about his head and body involuntarily.</hi> (S, K.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  A person <hi rend="ital">affected with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">زُكَام</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">rheum</hi>]: (S, K:) accord. to Sgh, [who seems, like J, not to have known <foreign lang="ar">أُرِضَ</foreign>,] from <foreign lang="ar">آرَضَهُ</foreign>; (Sgh, TA;) whereas by rule, [if from <foreign lang="ar">آرِضَهُ</foreign>,] it should be <foreign lang="ar">مُؤْرَضٌ</foreign>.
